overview.title: Overview
bullets: Technical analysis is a trading discipline that uses price charts, patterns, and indicators to anticipate future price movements.
It focuses on historical price data, volumes, and market metrics to identify trends and potential entry/exit points.
It is widely used across markets, including stocks, forex, crypto, and commodities.

items.title: Price Trends
items.desc: Prices tend to move in trends—up, down, or sideways—which often persist until a reversal occurs.

items.title: Support and Resistance
items.desc: Key levels where price may pause or reverse. Support is a floor where buying interest appears; resistance is a ceiling where selling interest emerges.

items.title: Market Cycles
items.desc: Prices often move in cycles influenced by psychology, macro conditions, and sentiment.

items.title: Moving Averages
points: Moving averages smooth price to reveal trend direction and potential reversal zones.
Common types include Simple Moving Average (SMA) and Exponential Moving Average (EMA).

items.title: Relative Strength Index (RSI)
points: RSI is a momentum oscillator that measures the speed and magnitude of price changes.
Readings above 70 often indicate overbought conditions; below 30 suggest oversold.

items.title: Bollinger Bands
points: A moving average with upper/lower bands to gauge volatility.
Bands widen when volatility is high and contract when volatility is low.

limitations.title: Limitations
bullets: Relies on historical data, which may not predict future movements accurately.
Prone to false signals in choppy or ranging markets.
Requires skill to interpret—different indicators can conflict, so confluence matters.
